text:
The usage information for Tomcat says that you can specify '-ajpid file' to 
tell where it to write the ajp12.id file. The start seems to ignore this option 
if supplied.

With 3.3b1 if you started Tomcat with '-Dtomcat.install=${TOMCAT_HOME} -
Dtomcat.home=/path/to/my/app' it would write the ajp12.id file 
to /path/to/my/app/conf/ajp12.id. With 3.3b2 unless you make tomcat.home point 
to where Tomcat's lib directory lives under, it won't find the .jar files. For 
this reason it wants tomcat.home to be $TOMCAT_HOME, and so it writes ajp12.id 
to $TOMCAT_HOME/conf/ajp12.id. With this, if you want more than one instance of 
Tomcat on the same system you need to create multiple copies of the Tomcat 
install.

In theory specifying a command line option like -ajpid at startup would fix 
this, but unfortunately it is ignored.

This is related to #2682. Maybe I'm missing something - maybe there is still a 
way to get Tomcat to write the ajp12.id file relative to some directory other 
than where Tomcat is installed.
creator: ben_kelley@ubsw.com
cmanolache@yahoo.com
text:
You can do that by specifying <ContextManager home="/path/to/my/app" /> 
in /path/to/my/app/conf/server.xml and starting tomcat with 
tomcat run -f /path/to/my/app/conf/server.xml.

Then all the files ( logs, webapps, etc ) including ajpid would go to my/app.

Note that TOMCAT_HOME and the system properties are very hard to keep around,
it is far better to use options in server.xml. I also fixed this, so your 
command line will work again - but I'm not sure it's the best way to do it.
